Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>
>Another factor is the kinds of sensors and outputs you use.  If you 
>use absolute sensors and outputs, e.g. "look north, south, east, 
>west" and "move north, south, east, or west," then there is a need 
>to rediscover the same principle more than once: if something is 
>perceived in a certain direction then move in that direction.  
>Because this principle would need to be discovered for each 
>available direction, there is more room for failure or subtle flaws 
>in at least one of the directions.
>
>On the other hand, if you use relative (i.e. egocentric) 
>representations, principles generally only need be discovered once.  
>For example, if something is in front of you, then move towards it.  
>Otherwise, if something is at angle from your front (notice- 
>relative), then turn until you point towards it.  These principles 
>apply in any position, and therefore are likely to end up more 
>accurate overall.
>  
>
Following on from this it occurs to me that domains such as prey capture 
aren't all that different to the roving eye type domains, that is we 
have a grid 'world' and an agent that moves over the grid, receives 
input from it and uses those inputs to make motor output decisions. The 
main difference being that in prey capture I'm using sector based 
inputs, and roving eyes generally use raster based inputs.

As I recall Derek and Philip's image recognition work uses an egocentric 
eye and this makes sense to me since the same pattern in different 
rotations only needs to be learned once, which then leads me to ask if 
an egocentric eye was used, or has been tried at playing Go. I don't 
think the eye in your paper used rotation did it Ken? Not to mention the 
zooming function which may or may not be useful depending on the type of 
board game.

Colin.
